Description: Body sherd (mended from three fragments) of Chian Simple Animal Style pottery phiale mesomphalos; cream slip; interior: glazed black; dot and billet pattern in added white; exterior: single row of large dots around rim above broken maeander pattern between pairs of lines; below, painted decoration consisting of lion (head and shoulder remaining) to right; elaborate rosette as filling ornament; at right, part of undetermined motif, possibly a tail; inscription on exterior.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Staatliche Museen zu Berlin. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Destroyed during WW2. Illustrated in Lemos 1991 and described by A. Furtwängler, ‘Erwerbungen der Antiken sammlungen in Deutschland’, AA 1889, 85-94, esp. 93-94 no. 11. See also K.A. Neugebauer, Führer durch das Antiquarium II Vasen, Berlin 1932, p. 29-30: Inv. 3140. “Vierzehn Scherben mit Ornamenten, Resten figürlicher Darstellungen und Inschriften, teils Firnismalerei auf weißem Überzug, teils rot und weiß auf gefirnißter Fläche…. Aphroditeheiligtum zu Naukratis im Nildelta.” The sherd belongs to the same vase as Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.63.1894. Lemos places this phiale in the Mature Animal Style, but the decoration is not typical of the style. The only filling ornament is the elaborate rosette set in front of the lion; such a rosette as the only filling ornament is commonly found in the later Chalice Style. The rim pattern and lion is also consistent with the Chalice Style. For parallels regarding the rosette, see Lemos no. 928 from Tocra and Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology NA67 and Oxford AN1896-1908-G.114.15. For parallels regarding the lion, see Lemos nos. 971 from Pitane and 972 from Kamiros.
Bibliographic references: Gardner 1888 / Naukratis II (p. 63, no. 739, pl. XXI, no. 739)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 680, no. 390)
Cook & Woodhead 1952 / Painted Inscriptions on Chiot Pottery (p. 165, no. 16, pl. 34, no. 1)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 270, no. 683, pl. 90)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2013) (phase 2)
